keyTakeAways: Republican leaders, including House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune, have refused to negotiate with Democrats over government funding, maintaining that negotiations should only occur after the shutdown ends.

Several rank-and-file Republican lawmakers, such as Sen. Tommy Tuberville, Rep. Jeff Van Drew, and Sen. Jim Justice, argue that President Donald Trump must become more directly involved to break the deadlock.
Trump has not engaged in direct talks with Democrats since before the shutdown began, though he has signaled openness to negotiation — with a condition that the government must open first.
Trump has taken actions to assert executive control, including laying off over 4,000 federal employees and halting funding for infrastructure and energy projects in Democratic-leaning areas.

Democrats, including Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Democrat Hakeem Jeffries, are urging Trump to re-engage, citing his influence as a key factor in ending the shutdown and securing policy extensions like Obamacare subsidies.
The current stalemate marks a departure from past shutdowns, where negotiations were common; now, both parties are attempting to outlast each other instead of reaching compromise.
Some Republicans, like Missouri Sen. Josh Hawley, have encouraged Democrats to contact Trump directly, asserting his accessibility and potential to resolve the crisis.
White House officials believe the shutdown has helped Trump consolidate power and gain leverage over federal operations, framing it as a strategic move rather than a failure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As a government shutdown drags on into late October 2025, Republican leaders such as House Speaker Mike Johnson and Senate Majority Leader John Thune have firmly rejected negotiations with Democrats, insisting that the shutdown must end before talks begin. However, several rank-and-file Republicans — including Senators Tommy Tuberville, Jim Justice, and Josh Hawley, and Representative Jeff Van Drew — are urging President Donald Trump to take a more direct role, arguing that his influence and political leverage are essential to breaking the deadlock. Trump has not personally engaged with Democratic leaders since the shutdown began, though he has signaled openness to talks with the condition that the government reopens first. Meanwhile, Democrats are pressing Trump to re-engage, citing his influence as critical to securing policy extensions like Obamacare subsidies. Trump’s administration has intensified the shutdown by cutting federal employee numbers — over 4,000 laid off, with more planned — and halting infrastructure funding in Democratic-leaning areas. While Republican leaders maintain that no negotiations are possible, the growing internal pressure within the GOP and the Democrats’ active appeal to Trump suggest a significant shift in political strategy, with both parties increasingly turning to Trump as the only figure capable of forcing a resolution.
title: We absolutely need him: Some in GOP say it’s time for Trump to get involved in shutdown talks even as leaders rebuff idea
